page.title: 02Landscape
page.content: The area splits naturally in to two halves. The western half, nearer the lake, contains most of the population, with Windermere village, the small village of Troutbeck Bridge to the NW and a large number of scattered, detached houses, large and small. Except in the NW of the area, the land rises quickly away from the lake to about 90 metres generally. At Orrest Head, just north of Windermere, it reaches 250m., giving spectacular views over the whole of the southern Lake District. The eastern half is an undulating, open area with small rocky outcrops and scattered farms. The ground rises gently towards the south to about 250m., while to the north it rises towards Sour Howes (478m.), the edge of the main lakeland hill mass.
